text: Number 644, Billy Don Franklin Boulden versus William C. Holman Warden.
Mr. Chief Justice, other members of this Court.
Was the Witherspoon point raised below?
We did not -- I did not raise it below on the Fifth Circuit, no sir.
What jurisdiction we have to consider here?
I believe that in my brief, I have found a case whereby you find it Your Honor you can consider in Clifford -- Stuart versus Sea Groups, the Court pointed out that matters if were not passed on --
Federal court.
Sir?
That's what the federal court?
It's from this Court --
You are the better authority, Mapp against Ohio.
Sir?
Mapp against Ohio is pretty good authority to you.
This is a federal -- this is Supreme Court decision that I was referring to here.
Does this case have it heard from the federal court?
Yes, it's on appeal it started in state court of Alabama.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
Was that denied?
That was denied.
I beg your pardon.
It's the point that I'm going to bring out.
Did the man who was supposed to have said that testified?
Yes sir, because --
Did he denied.
Billy Boulden said that there was an officer Good in another -- another patrolman there.
But how about the one who was suppose to have said it, did he testified?
Yes, sir.
And he denied it, did he?
Yes, sir.
Well, that's all I want to hear.
And of course, Judge Johnson, the district judge had to identify that both of their testimonies.
Would you mind telling us what the reason for the removal as to the other county?
Yes, sir.
It was a matter of security.
Yes, sir.
Yes, alright.
Now, there was this something said about he wasn't warned of his rights at that time before this first confession was taken.
Was that the law of Alabama at that time that he was entitled to a lawyer at the time he's being interrogated by the police?
Incidentally, this trial, I would point out to the Court that the murder occurred on the first of May.
Yes.
And the trial was May the 27th through the 29th.
Of '64 sir.
Prior to Escobedo or --
Prior to either one.
I should like to point out to the Court that --
This Captain Williams said that he was told the petitioner that he was entitled to a lawyer by the time of his being -- the time he's being interrogated?
Yes sir.
Was that the law of Alabama?
It was not an absolute requirement throughout Alabama but in that circuit, Judge Bloodworth was really an advanced judge in thinking at that time.
Because it wasn't the law generally, it wasn't any constitutional requirement.
Well, it wasn't at that time judge.
I beg your pardon?
It was not an absolute requirement at that time.
What time was this?
What time?
Was it night?
I believe it was around 10:30 - 11 o'clock somewhere in that.
At night?
At night, sir.
As a matter of fact, he said, "I wish to make the following voluntary statement to E. B. Watts."
It is my understanding, Mr. Watts asking those questions and then wrote it down.
But he says "I, Billy Watts
Yes sir.
May it please the Honorable Court.
Well, he was murdered and she was not an eyewitness to it.
That's correct sir.
How old was he?
19, never been in trouble before.
He had a pistol, didn't he?
No.
Did he have a pistol?
Yes.
Yes, sir, I think he did.
Well, he said he did.
In some of his confessions, he did and they never show it up in the trial.
And the girl said he did.
That's correct.
Is there any indication that anybody else could have done this?
He has said so, Your Honor.
What?
He has said so later when he got before the governor.
How long was it after the girl ran to the street or the road, highway, when the officers came back down where he was killed?
Very short.
What?
Very shortly.
How far was it?
Less than about a half mile to a mile.
And they came right back?
Very shortly, Your Honor.
That's the information, the only information they have and what she gave them?
This is correct.
That this boy had killed him.
That's right.
Where was he then?
He was back down in the woods.
I understand.
This is what he told when he got in the Governor's office, what he told when we started in the District Court, this is when I got in the case in the District Court.
